job_title: Senior EHR Analyst in Lexington, KY
pros: Work-life balance is excellent and benefits are almost unbeatable (at least locally). Managers are generally great and you usually have all the support you need to do well and succeed.
cons: Those pros stated, there's not much *reason* to do well and succeed, because you won't be paid well. UK knows their benefits are great so they use them as an excuse to lag behind the rest of the market in pay. Outside hires will do best, because UK recognizes they kind of have to compete; if you're an internal hire moving from one area to another, your experience will be functionally cut in half, which for many employees means they get dropped into the entry levels of a salary grade even if they're mid-career. IT recently performed some salary adjustments, but those are largely a joke—in my case I received a ~12% bump, which put me right about where I should have been when I *started* in the role four years ago. Also worth noting, for anyone considering coming to UK Healthcare, future pay increases will "merit-based" but not in any meaningful sense. They are also using that new merit-based model as an excuse to eliminate the previous across the board increases all employees not on probation would receive. So now your performance matters, and you might get rewarded for it, but if you don't you'll be out of luck when cost-of-living goes up.

pros: Job is easy. Benefits aren't terrible.
cons: Incredibly toxic. People will add on to "incidents" to make them sound worse. Managers avoid confrontation at all costs and try to force their employees to do it OR treat the employees who speak up like they're the problem. Some bullying, lying, sexism. Policies aren't uniformly enforced. They're write-up happy. The company actually creates policies that literally have no impact on the job so they can have a reason to "coach" you. An example is COVID screenings. Do them BEFORE your shift or be coached. Even if you have all the symptoms and your family has tested positive, you're still are expected to work. They write up for every tiny thing even if you're in a training period. They have a certain type of mistake that you can only make 4 times your entire career or you're fired. People who have been here for a long time lose their job over this because it's delaying the inevitable. Mistakes happen. I could go on and on. It's not the worst place to work but it is designed to not be permanent.

- Work life balance and culture is heavily dependent upon your department. Though there are overall university rules, a lot of the day to day work environment can be dictated by those individual. Some environments I’ve worked in have been positive, and some have been toxic.

review_title: Fantastic benefits, upper management and base pay needs work...
pros: The Healthcare, insurance, and retirement match benefits are fantastic and probably the best in Lexington. Great work culture (usually) and lot's of opportunity to explore other areas of passion or be in on unique projects.
cons:
The biggest con is that the extremely low base pay just is insulting almost. Compared to the other that's one of the lowest in the city. Living on a single person income is extremely difficult on this salary. Especially when you HAVE to pay for parking and the other benefits. The take home pay just isn't enough.

Additionally, upper management needs some work. They claim to be very transparent on every decision they make, but those decisions are often not thought through. Or, if upper management asks for advice, it's ignored / not taken. Some lower level employees aren't awarded the same opportunities or praise as others who are "the favorite". Office restructures can be bumpy, but if you lose 5+ people you can't force all the other employees that stuck around absorb all their responsibilities. And if you do force them to absorb those responsibilities ... make sure that person is compensated appropriately.

pros: Decent benefits, but not work the risk.
cons: Your safety and security is based around an hourly rate of 12.50. You’ll never not wonder before your shift if it’s going to be the worst night you’ve experienced because each bad night is progressively worse than the last. You’ll be thrown to the wolves, beat up, verbally assaulted, and endure so much mentally for only 12.50 an hour base pay. The administration does not care about you and no one has your best interest at heart. Trust no one. The turn over rate is high, and you’ll never be fully staffed to handle violent situations. You’ll work with COVID positive patients with no hazard pay. You’ll get a free thing of left over bagels from the cafeteria and that’s your pat on the back. The relationships amongst the administration are political and very corrupt, so your complaints about management are never safe. This job will deteriorate your very soul with no room for healing. This facility is a psych ward nightmare.

pros: I loved my job. Meeting new people from all parts of the world and making lifelong friends was worth it. I loved hosting programs and educating residents on a variety of topics. The 'on call' hours were really not bad, but my experience will vary from everyone else's (varies from hall to hall). The RA class you must take if you get the job helped a bit in professional development.
cons:
The Office of ResLife (Residence Life) is absolutely AWFUL. This is the saddest part of the job: they made me dislike it. 

Upper management is pretty much non-existent, they tell you that you as an RA are the foundation of the organization and that they care about you, which is pretty much false. They are expecting more out of RAs to the point that if you don't make it your life goal to be a stellar show-off RA, you are looked down upon and harassed to leave. 

No support from some HDs (Hall Directors), will vary hall to hall.

Boring, pointless training that really does not help you.

No clear communication between upper leadership and your own hall.

High turnover of employees, including HDs.

High restrictions on out-of-hall overnights (and getting progressively worse)

Minimum wage for working front desk that actually just ends up adding up to what you would've paid for housing.

Too little consistency in policy enforcement and standards between halls.

Will not accommodate to semester-long internships or abroad experiences (I know some people that have quit with a full 2-weeks notice, but ResLife shows them as "fired" in their good standing records).

review_title: University of Kentucky EE Grad Student
pros: The flexibility provided by working in an academic setting is a strong reason to work at any University, and the University of Kentucky is no exception. As a graduate student in electrical engineering, the cost of completing your education is covered by the working for a professor as a teaching or research assistant in addition to standard living expenses. Work hours are flexible, and job performance is judged upon projects completed, not how many hours you show your face. It's hard to compare UK with working at any other University as I have never spent much time at any other, but it has been my favorite job so far.
cons: Parking is terrible and very expensive. Purchasing the required lot passes can run between 100-200$, and parking on the street is impossible during Fall and Spring semesters. The parking employees are very quick to ticket and tow cars as well. Some (what I consider unfair) downsides are that you aren't really making any money compared to what you can make working in the private sector with your BS; working to get a MS or PhD will result in years of working for approximately 20k. Job mobility is limited as you are a student employee and are expected to work for a professor until completion of your degree.

pros: Great benefits. Actually graduated from COE, and had a pretty great education. Basketball team is awesome.
cons: Pay is 'way' below industry standard. Management is complacent, immune to change, and mostly comprised of individuals who've worked there for 10-20 years. You'll get a 2% raise every year regardless of your performance review. Those who under-excel are actually promoted to various departments to avoid conflict. They'll sit there till forced-retirement. Most executive maneuvers are stubbornly inefficient, and the bureaucratic red-tape is the worst I've ever seen. I've never had to jump through so many hoops just to get simple tasks done such as approval for inventory orders (3 weeks), or submitting corrections for spelling mistakes on departmental website (not even my job, but I noticed...2 weeks). If you can imagine a 90's sitcom portrayal of the DMV...you've got the picture. Academic faculty, on the other hand, is great. Law Department seems to be on top of their game as well. I was in engineering, and it was literally the easiest job of my life. Learned absolutely nothing. Thank goodness I got on at Lockheed!

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington, KY
pros: Teaching courses under a supervisor gives you many opportunities to experiment and implement instruction that can best serve the needs of the students. It is also great to get your full tuition payed for while also making a minimally living wage from the University when taking graduate school classes. You will also make meaningful connections with educators within and outside of your department that could provide opportunities to you that you never knew existed
cons: You can sometimes be relegated to completing asinine work such as printing documents for your supervisor when she/he could do it herself/himself, compiling binders of documents/research information whenever your supervisor could have done it herself/himself, and the completion of asinine tasks that not even a secretary would be expected to complete. I was once called down from my upstairs office to meet with my supervisor in her office to then be told to walk down three rooms to retrieve a document that she had just printed. It is that kind of nonsense that can really grind your gears whenever you are preparing for your own lessons, completing your own coursework, and trying to serve the University in an actual impactful way. Of course...this all depends on who your supervisor is. Therefore, take my advice as a very specific case of working for a very specific individual.

pros: The atmosphere is really friendly and the employer does so many different things that it's really easy to find a good department, or if you wish and are qualified, to switch departments easily in house. The university offers an employee education program (EEP) in which employees are granted 6 free credit hours a semester in order to better themselves. It's a great way for you to work your way up gradually. The employees are friendly and always willing to help. I can only speak for my department (CMS), but the hospital is one of the best around, and the departments function well enough with each other.
cons: It's one of the largest employers in the city and they know it. A lot of the positions inside the hospital don't have much upward movement minus the EEP that they do offer, which is great. Being part of such a large employer means you'll have to put up with your typical mandatory corporation type meetings that may seem a little boring. They don't really do a great job at offering pay raises to lower level workers for continued loyalty.

pros: Cost of living in Lexington is low. Decent salary
cons: Do not value employees. You are disposable.

pros: Good benefits if you are full time staff (not much if you are part time/trainee/ postdoc). There is some flexibility on the work schedule. City not too bad - it takes 5 miles drive to get to work. Leadership is paid top dollars but regular staff people and postdoc are way below the NIH pay scale. Houses are not too expensive (unlike other areas of US) but still not affordable for many UKY people.
cons: Not much room for professional growth. No pay raises based on the experience (if you do well your job you might get 5% merit-based pay increase, but most people get 1-2% pay raise which is joke compared to increasing prices of living). Parking is horrible on campus (you could get a good spot for extra ~$100/month otherwise be ready to pay $400 for parking permit. Student enrollment number sare growing each year - there are more people on campus and more cars. Commuting to (and off) work becomes problematic in rush hours (but still not bad as traffic in big metropolitan cities).

review_title: Take Better Care of Graduate Students!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Cost of living is pretty low in Lexington
cons: If you're not paid well, then it doesn't matter how low cost of living is. Graduate student salaries are ridiculously low with the lowest salary being around $10,000 for students in entomology. The only graduate students receiving somewhat fair pay are in the hard sciences like Biology. Many graduate students are living along the poverty line if not in poverty already. Graduate students sometimes lose their funding because funding is not always guaranteed for the duration of their studies. Many graduate students complain of being overworked and underpaid. Race/racism is an issue and graduate students of color had to push the administration last year to address it. New graduate housing is well beyond what students can afford and their salaries are not being increased.

job_title: Staff Support Associate II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Good benefits and compensation package. Working with students as they obtain their degrees. And the opportunity to work with amazing people. You also have the opportunity to take 2 courses for free per semester. The current president has implemented a lot of changes for the better unlike his predecessor. There has been a lot of growth and development.
cons: There is not any consistency with pay. If you worked for a department with very little funding, you most likely will receive less pay than someone who may be in lets say the medical department. The person may be doing the exact same job as you but may receive thousands more than you. It is definitely about who you know. I've seen employees come in with very little experience who received positions but for those looking to move up, it may be more difficult if you do not know the right people. Employees also pay for parking every month but the garage is so far away and you are not guaranteed a parking spot. If you dare leave for lunch, you may not have a place to park when you come back

review_title: Difficult to Advance in Some Offices
job_title: Support Associate II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Benefits (until COVID)/retirement, hours, holiday/vacation/maternity leave allowance is great, difficult to be fired (a pro for some, con for their co-workers), the right supervisor makes for a good work environment
cons: Low pay if you aren't at a certain grade or above, upgrades needed in many buildings, terrible parking, some benefits have been cut due to COVID, little to no room for advancement in some offices, forced 'office fun' when some employees don't really have time for it and we have to spend our own money on it, no compensation for extra effort or time - some can float by while others work hard and both are treated the same and at certain times of year I work through lunch and after hours without pay, the wrong supervisor results in constant frustration

pros: Gain some good experience in a teaching environment. Refresh on the basics and enhance your communication ability for relaying CS concepts to the uninitiated, useful skills for the future. Rewarding watching students skills progress in part due to your tutelage.
cons: Antiquated method for grading assignments, sending out feedback, and maintaining a gradebook. Because of this most of your time will be spent performing these duties, leaving less time for class preparation. The biggest problem is that you are only allotted 10 "billable" hours per week, but will consistently work more than that ( 2 hours in class, 2 hours in office hours, 1 hour weekly TA meeting, anywhere from 1-2 hours answering students emails or questions, then anywhere from 4-6 hours grading assignments, doing feedback, and updating gradebook), that's not to mention the requests to come in for "volunteer" hours to help during lecture sections or exam grading.

review_title: Insular Good Old Boy Network, Kill the Messenger Attitude
pros: They offer a good benefits package.
cons: I spent one year as a faculty member and was never even given the opportunity to give feedback about administrators who were pitifully under-qualified to be supervising faculty or managing programs or students. When I inquired with the dean's office about where to provide feedback about my immediate supervisors, I was told that there wasn't any but they would keep that in mind for the future. When I inquired about curriculum, I was met with lack of understanding of what a curriculum is. In my dept, undergraduate student assistants worked in admissions, managed student grades and student evaluations, and were given authority over faculty on many occasions. Almost every aspect of the program went unchecked. I had very high student evaluations and annual review but left after one year, so discouraged about any prospect for professional growth or making the department any better. Filling classrooms with paying students was the bottom line.

pros:
The biggest pro to working at UK Chandler Hospital has to be the good benefits such as 401k matching. 
Tuition assistance
Health insurance
Dental insurance
cons:
Pay is only Ok
Raises are lousy, everyone gets the same 2% no matter if they work hard or not.
Favoritism is absolutely the standard mode of operation.
There is nothing based on merit.
Policies and procedures are hopelessly outdated.
Incredibly top heavy with managers and assistant managers. Everyone has an assistant manager. Funny thing is, the managers don't do anything except walk around talking about their vacations and where they are going to lunch, etc. Managers get bonuses. The people who do all the real work get the lousy 2%. Also, regular staff employees are constantly given additional work assignments(including some that they have not received any training for) and they receive absolutely no additional pay for any of it. If you question any of this, the attitude is basically "be happy to have a job". Horrible, absolutely horrible management.

review_title: Have faith in the UK Healthcare initiative.  UK sets standards to promote the best patient experience possible.
pros: Benefits and discounts are outstanding!  Retirement is 200% match.  Tuition assistance is the best you will ever receive.  Pay is so-so.
cons: Depends on the department you work in. There are some areas that are heavy in office politics and if you mix that with poor interpersonal and professional skills it can get unnecessarily stressful. There is entirely too much favoritism. Some employees aren't held to the same standards as others on their team.  There is also a lot of bully-like behavior that is permitted and it causes hostile working conditions. Very strict time management.  Employees are given occurrences even if only a minute late.  Employees must pay for parking.  Very difficult to transfer to work in another department. Too much held on "who you know".

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: I loved the tuition plan offered. I ended up getting a minor in spanish (which I believe led to my new job) all for free! The department I worked in (King Library) was close knit, but not in a cliquish way. My co-workers were supportive when needed and I was always encouraged to continue doing a good job.
cons: The University can be stagnant. Progressive policies were usually shot down. One of our co-workers was gay and had to accept the fact that his partner would receive none of his benefits if he died. Some of the upper level management was absolutely clueless having obtained a PhD and getting their position through the "grapevine." UK can be very much about who you know, but it's like that almost everywhere.

job_title: Customer Relations Associate in Lexington, KY
pros: The job was pretty laid back and had a good amount of downtime. If you lik talking to people, it is definitely a good job to have.
cons:
-Management is pretty much non-existent. 

-Co-workers determine your job security. You could do nearly everything right and because of not satisfying co-workers, you can be terminated. 

-Pay starts low, unless you can show you have significant customer service experience; although, shift differential is a plus and weekend pay on any hour after 3.30 p.m. working at 12:30 p.m. to 9 p.m. shift

review_title: Broken University system inhibits growth of facility
pros:
Flexible working hours and off-campus location make it easier to work around parking and traffic
Serving the animal and public health of the Bluegrass
Great for individuals who don't like being micro-managed
cons:
Broken University budget system allows employees who have been here too long to remain in positions out of fear of losing them in the budget crunch
UK can't properly recruit and retain more qualified individuals because they can't compete in terms of salary and benefits
Little room for vertical movement based on how job descriptions and in-house promotions system is structured
Morale is in the can due to recent budget cuts from the state and federal level(s)

review_title: Loved working there but felt unappreciated
pros: I loved my co-workers and the benefits were great. Pay is typically comparable, if not slightly higher to other companies in the Lexington area.
cons: There is an overall lack of appreciation for employees when it comes to UK's practice of promoting or transferring to other positions within the university. There is very much so a culture of "it's not what you know, its who you know." I saw this type of favoritism play out on a few occasions both during my employment and after I had left, with certain employees being terminated for minor infractions, while other employees could commit more serious breaches of policy, but because they were "in good" with the right supervisor or high-level employee within the university, discrepancies would be over-looked.

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: None that I can think of.  Benefits were great because they were bought out by UK but everything else was just Eastern State.
cons: Where to start. Low pay. Dangerous working conditions due to threats from management about lowering restraints. Injuries that occur on the job aren't even followed up on by management.  Upper level staff such as nurses (some of them) sit in conference rooms all night long and don't come out to help the limited number of MHAs on the floor. Lots of cliches within the hospital and upper management is a joke. Save yourself the migraines and massive beatings and don't work here. Pay is disgusting for what you are expected to do especially on some of the units. The long term care unit pays more for less patients and less work yet acute care staff are expected to go there to work for less pay.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Lexington, KY
pros: Job Security. Once hired, you can work at UK for the rest of your life if you want. Even if you're lazy. (As long as you don't screw up severely)
cons: Things move at a snail pace all over the organization. Salary inequality is severe. Your supervisors make 3-4x your salary without producing 3-4x your knowledge or work, simply because they have friends in the right places and/or have been at the organization a long time.

review_title: No room for advancement due to political picks, not experience based.
pros: Staff are wonderful despite unsafe environment. They are lucky to have dedicated people working for them despite being grossly underpaid.
cons: UK took over as management, it is still contract based however. Meaning that consistently getting a raise like you would get working at the VA is not occuring. So working at the VA for 10 as opposed to working for ESH 10 will result in financial stagnation.

review_title: Great place to work, but be prepared for continual frustrations.
job_title: IS Technical Support Specialist III in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Generous benefits package, good health care options via the University's Medical Center
cons:
Processes are very very difficult to alter.  In general, people conflate the processes they use and their job as a whole (i.e. "my job is to sort through this paper bill to search for mistakes", as opposed to "my job is to ensure that the monthly billing process is accurate.") which leads to refusals to change business processes.

VERY difficult to move up the ladder.  Promotions aren't common, and typically only happen when a person moves away from their current department into a higher position.

review_title: The University of Kentucky Department of Otolaryngology is a great place to work.
job_title: Staff Support Associate II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros:
Working with the Department of Otolaryngology was the best job I have ever had. Great staff, excellent physicians, overall an  outstanding workplace. Everyone in the department went above and beyond the call of duty to help the department excel. 

The university has a very good benefits package.The two times employee 403K deposit match is particularly generous.
cons:
UK is a large organization and the bureaucracy is often cumbersome. 

State budget cuts often prevent employee raises.It is not unusual to go two or more years without a raise.

Campus parking is a nightmare, particularly during football season when stadium lots are unavailable.

University management doesn't pay attention to feedback from staff. Many surveys are taken, few changes ever happen.

review_title: Part time administrative assistant work at a research center was enjoyable and pay was fine
pros: I enjoyed the work and community at the research center.  Working for UK builds instant connection with people in Lexington, since the whole region really identifies with the university and everyone follows the basketball team!  :)  I had great coworkers, Lexington is a lovely city, and the campus is very pleasant.  It was great to learn more about the work the university sponsored through grants and other funding and to interact with the graduate student and research community.
cons: It was challenging navigating the larger university policies.  It's a really big organization and it was easy to feel lost within the bigger picture.

review_title: Current STEPS employee at UK for over 2 years.
job_title: Remote Medical Coder CPC in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: I like working at UK because they are a diverse organization that values and shows appreciation for their employees, even the temporary ones. Once hired, the benefits are superior and the salary is fairly competitive. Even with the recent budget cuts over the past couple of years, they've found a way to still post a few permanent positions and give a slight salary increase to the permanent employees, another (tangible) indication of the appreciation they show. Department heads send emails regularly showing how well the department is doing and expressing their gratitude for work well done.
cons: It can take a few years to get hired as permanent.

pros: Flexible schedule. Changes occur more often but for the most part the job requirement is flexible. Mostly friendly environment. Department chair is very nice and accommodating.
cons: Reporting an injustice Suffered from a superior is a waste of time. Because nothing will be done about it. Sometimes the victim gets victimized again for reporting. Seems to be the accepted culture. Very rare will a supervisor get punished for improper behavior.

pros: retirement benefits and HR department are top notch
cons: old boys network and instrusive mass group emails about 1) career circumstances/activities of top brass, 2) UK bookstore apparel, 3) other sources sanctioned by UK that do not offer an "unsubscribe" button

review_title: It was okay. All UK salaries can be found on www.kentucky.com info center, good luck.
job_title: Staff Support Associate II in Lexington, KY
pros: 403b, you contribute 5%, they contribute 10%, 100% vested from day 1. Health insurance is $25 per month for basic individual coverage. They have a work/life department and encourage supervisors to let their employees take advantage of those options.
cons: Bureaucracy, little opportunity to move up, parking (you have to pay for it), my position was a boring dead end job, working with people who are content in boring dead end jobs. Because the whole area I worked in was bored, it gave time for people to create little petty arguments, which created a lot of stress for all involved.

review_title: A very small part of the UK Healthcare Enterprise
pros: Opportunities usually exist to work as much or as little as you want, benefits are available to most employees although they are extremely expensive if part-time, constantly changing workplace, rapidly expanding facility, and a reasonably friendly place to work for, by healthcare standards.
cons: The majority of full-time employees seem to be there for retirement benefits, extreme top-down organizational hierarchy, limited horizontal or vertical movement by employees, constantly changing healthcare landscape makes long-term planning tenuous and questionable at best.

pros: Very open and friendly environment. New management structure is more rigid and focused on metrics. Lots of change.
cons: As momentum has been made on implementing change, less focus has been on the value of the metrics, and actually making something happen. Student perspective is less about the name change of the departments or how they are organized. They care about their use of infrastructure to gain their education. The starving lower levels of support and technology maintenance teams are left wondering about the value of "change".

job_title: Ticket Office Associate in Lexington, KY
pros: I really love the Fine Arts Department here at UK! I work in the Singletary Center and have had nothing but lovely interactions with the staff and other student workers. You really get to know people in the department, which is especially beneficial as a student in the department.
cons: UK isn't required to pay Lexington minimum wage to it's student workers since it is a state organization. Therefore, while I make above KY minimum wage, I don't make Lexington minimum wage which isn't great. Also the university doesn't allocate a lot of money to the Fine Arts Department, but this affects me as a student more than it does me as a part-time employee.

pros: Lexington is a very comfy city and the people here is very nice. Being a teaching assistant here, you only need to work 20 hr/week, so the workload isn't too much. The living cost is pretty low, so you can absolutely make your end meet.
cons: The parking is so packed here. As an employee, you need to get up very early to park. And the students here seem to detest to learn. I am teaching statistics, maybe it is because they don't like math.

review_title: Don't work as a STEPS employee
pros: You're told that there is room for advancement. I've seen it but not experienced it personally.
cons:
The STEPS system is exploitative. You work full-time on site and have no paid holidays, vacation time or benefits of any kind. Do not accept a position if it is STEPS.

I was also told by my direct manager that I would be receiving a raise. She sent me confirmation from the appropriate department that the raise would take effect, but then I never receive said raise. When I brought it up with the managers above her a couple months later, I was told that there was a pay freeze.

pros: Complex and diverse patient population. Good education benefits (if attend in their system).  Various ancillary services and organization driven to excel.
cons: Very poor teamwork between professions and departments, especially with Physicians. Large number in executive leadership, middle management has little power or control to initiate change.  Focus is on improving hospital rankings sometimes at the expense of outcome improvement or improving the quality of care for patients. You must be a self-driven learner since there is little support for direct care staff for ongoing (after orientation) continuing education. Expensive and inadequate ( >$400/year - 2017).  Pay lower than most in the area, with greater responsibility.

review_title: UK is a pretty decent place to work, but it depends mostly on who you know vs what you know.  No raises for many years.
job_title: Staff Support Associate II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Great benefits, some good people.  The retirement plan is awesome, health insurance is ok.  I had HMO and did not have any real complaints.
cons: Some of the higher paid doctors and most faculty can be insufferable.  There is certainly a bit of snobbery on campus.  Did not get many raises, since there was a freeze while I was there.

pros: UK had a great signing package for a poor grad student. When I signed on, I felt like I was on top of the world.
cons:
But UK, like many institutions of higher learning, has many problems with politics, nepotism, and preserving the reputation of athletics over everything else.
I don't work at a U now. I make more in the construction industry than I ever did teaching.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: The main draw is the great benefits. Salary is good. Benefits are great, especially 403b matching, etc.
cons: Management at the department level. I can only speak for my experience but my manager was the worst I've ever had and it is not even close. She constantly spoke out of both sides of her mouth and definitely played favorites. There was always drama in the office and there was always dissatisfaction and most of that tied directly to the mgr.

pros:
Competitive pay compared to other universities.
Unlimited access to labs and softwares.  Good library (building and collections).
There is a movement among profs to provide a stimulating environment with seminars and event (Engineering Day) 
There used to be a lot of faculty migration, but now I see better retention.
More and more cooperations with industry.  Great job on internship program at College of Engineering.  Engineering students are encouraged to take internship. 
If you want to update your resume, the school is really helpful (resume day, class, events)
cons:
Limited number of graduate students.
Not much national recognition.
Not much award available.
Not much alumni connections/presences.

pros:
Great work life balance, it's rare that you work weekends .  The healthcare unit does work weekends but usually with plenty of notice
Decent benefits, great for Kentucky.  I say decent because in the high tech sector their benefits are middle of the road.  For Lexington, they are great.
Training, especially for new managers is a thing.  Now professional training is non-existent.  They spend less on training than they do on food at doctor receptions, but between taking classes and the in-house training there is some good stuff to be found.
Nice people.  Most folks are  willing to help, especially if you have a major life issue.
Very kind to new parents.  The generous sick leave and ability to work remotely really help with young kids.
Lots of vacation, like insane amounts, plus dedicated sick leave, and the pace is slow enough you get to use it.
Great place to heal.  If you've lost a loved one, experienced a bitter divorce, been wrecked by a horrible job, UK is a great place to recover and rebuild.
cons:
Management has little vision or skill.  They regurgitate what they read in trade rags, rarely publicly disagree.  Many stay at UK for decades, with the high achievers growing frustrated and leaving.  It's almost a perfect sorting system for mediocrity. All significant strategic planning is outsourced to consultants, with slavish implementation of their recommendations afterwards.  The only exception is anything that would be too painful to implement culturally.
Politics, politics, politics.  Because mainly the high achievers leave (firing after the first 90 days is hard, if you manage it you're a very special sort of idiot), everything is super consensus driven.  The problem is that if you have 2 idiots, 3 uninformed, and 1 expert guess what the consensus generates?  Also, if anyones feelings are hurt in the process, they may well come back and knife the offender in the back 10 years later.
Micromanagement and distrust are fundamental to the organization,  assume everyone is 1-2 levels lower compared to other organizations.   Managers are more like team leads, directors managers.
Degree snobs.  Especially in the tech sector, there is no correlation between degree and ability.  Expect to be marginalized if you don't have a master's degree at least.

review_title: Great experience working for a growing university.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Lots of opportunities to get to know faculty and staff members -- this is great for networking as they are usually very willing to help you down the road.  Supervisors provide opportunities for growth and give you lots of responsibilities.  Also, my supervisor was always very respectful of the fact that I was taking graduate courses full-time -- she never gave me too much work at a time and was always there to help.
cons: Sometimes the work was unpredictable -- this is some to do with the nature of the environment, but was also caused by disorganization within the department.

pros: Great 2x IRA match:  hope it lasts.  Good work / family balance.  Collegial coworkers.  Pleasant environment.  Reasonable openness.  There are some good people here that go above and beyond.
cons: No raises for faculty and staff for the last two years, heading for three years now.  Crazy escalating parking fees.  Many people actively hiding their incompetence / do-nothingness rather than actually doing their job.  Lots of deadwood that cannot be pruned.  Ossified management structure.

pros: It offers great experience as a student. Coming in with zero work experience in this field can be a challenge. The pay is not bad, other than the fact as a student it is based on hours worked. Trying to juggle classes and work has not been difficult. What has been difficult is getting classes scheduled so that I can create a working schedule. The people I work with are really flexible so this has not been an issue.
cons: I am considered a "student employee." Hourly wages as opposed to a salary contract.

pros:
The main academic area is pretty small, and the research activity is limited.
If you work for someone who has money, you're pretty much left alone by the other parts of campus.
cons:
Lexington isn't great if you're not college-aged and single.  Between Keeneland, UK sports, and downtown there's plenty to go and do. Just feels like you see the same people all the time.

If you're over 30 and not married or not have kids you will be looked at funny and shunned.

review_title: Good mid level research university with low pay scale
job_title: Research Associate Professor in Lexington, KY
pros: There is a moderate amount of support for teaching, and some support for research.   The university supports travel to conventions, has generally good IT facilities for teaching and speakers, and generally provides support for promotions.
cons: Raises have been few and far between.  The longer you stay, the further you get behind.  Good stepping stone university for upward mobility.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros:
Employee Education Program benefits allows employee to attend UK tuition free for 6 hours a semester, or a dependent for 50% off tuition
Reasonable rates on insurance, PPO is much more convenient than the HMO
cons: If there is a  heavy snow/ice day and you work in the hospital, know that you can not miss work...most people make arrangements to sleep at the hospital or local hotel the night before.  Some employees of 30 years have been fired for calling in on snow days.  Not sure if it's a con, but just be aware.

pros: Benefits are pretty good. Retirement benefits are especially generous. They have a flex spending account, as well as decent co-pays for office visits.
cons: It's all about appearances. They like big posters with achievements on them, but the actual behind the scenes action involves 50% lazy employees who know how to game the system and 50% employees who make up for the other group...until they get tired of working for peanuts while someone else doesn't have to work to get paid.

pros:
Work schedule is crafted around class schedule.
Required hours per week are minimal with the option to pick up more shifts
Co-workers are very easy to get along with and make work enjoyable
Patrons are usually also very enjoyable
The work isn't difficult
cons:
Pay & raises are sub-par compared to other on/off campus positions
Management can be very rigid even when unnecessary
Many of the meetings during the semester, especially for supervisors & managers, are more of a waste of time

job_title: Information Technology Services in Lexington, KY
pros: Great health insurance and other benefits. Employee gym is $7/month and there are some nice employee discounts, like cheap Fitbits and discount dry cleaning. Nice amount of paid holidays--more than other offices I've worked in. Full-time employees got a paid week off in December.
cons:
Overall, I really disliked working for UK. My direct supervisor had dreadful communication skills and did not treat employees with kindness. For example, my supervisor didn't even check on me or ask if I was okay after I informed her that I was in a serious car accident. No "Are you alright?" or ANYTHING. Also, I barely got to see my supervisor in person and nearly all communication was done via email. SO many emails. SO many meetings. There were days when I'd spend 6 hours in meetings--many of which were unnecessary.

It's an absolutely dreadful parking situation. Employees pay $37/month to park and are not guaranteed a spot. If you get to work after 8:30am you are pretty much screwed. If you need to leave at lunch for an appointment or errand, you are also pretty much screwed when you want to come back and park.

The only thing more dreadful than the parking situation is the maternity leave and lack of accommodation for nursing mothers. I didn't deal with this personally but I watched coworkers deal with this and I was just horrified. Very little time off, very little flexibility with maternity leave, and very few places for mothers to nurse on campus. If you are looking into working for UK and you are either a nursing mother or may one day be a nursing mother, I recommend reading up on what you're getting into.

pros: I worked at UK for 10 years. It’s a wonderful facility that provides exceptional healthcare and values its employees. Very supportive of nursing staff, has a culture of mutual respect, physicians are not allowed to “talk down” to staff, and an environment conducive to learning. Plenty of opportunities for growth and benefits that are fantastic (200% matching on your retirement!). Insurance benefits are also very good and very affordable. Educational assistance is excellent. I can’t say enough good things about working here. Also, CNO, Colleen Swartz is a class act and very approachable and genuine.
cons: Parking can be difficult

review_title: UKY is nice place to work
pros:
UKY was in the top 10 in USA for doing postdoctoral research!
It is a nice peaceful city, great for families and very affordable housing. Groceries are OK  but not great for younger people looking for lots of social life...
cons: The public transportation is bad and the parking for employees is ~400 per year. Post-docs could get only up to 75% of NIH based salary for the position and experience (this is internal UKY policy).

pros: UK has a good benefits package available for employees.
cons: We were never offered the chance to submit feedback on our immediate supervisors. When these concerns, and others, were brought to the associate dean, we were brushed aside as inconsequential. Very disappointed in the college's ability to look beyond merely getting instructors in classrooms and toward the potential for sustaining the growth of the department.

review_title: Great colleagues and work flexibility if you are willing to accept a lower salary.
pros: The work-life balance is excellent. Benefits are good. My immediate supervisor understands the need for flexibility in my schedule. I work in a research laboratory and realize these pros may not apply to other positions at UK.
cons: Salaries are typically lower in the academic setting compared to other companies. Your work environment and job satisfaction depend highly upon the individual supervisor. UK does not have a daycare program for its employees. Parking is expensive and inconvenient.

job_title: Student Philanthropy Manager in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Working with the University of Kentucky as a Student Employee provides excellent, real-world, experience, while allowing flexible scheduling - as a Student Employee, you are a student first. I have been working at the Office of Philanthropy in Annual Giving for a little over 2 years now. I started as a Student Philanthropy Officer/ Caller.  After 5 months, I was promoted to a Training position. After 5 more months, I was promoted to Manager. As a manager, you are given the opportunity to come in on days off to make calls and raise support. However, as a Manager, your main task is to run the call center. You are the voice of the coordinator on the floor. This job has provided me invaluable experience in the Sales field as well as the Management field, including, handling rejection, building rapport, engaging with people you may not have had the opportunity to otherwise, interviewing potential candidates for employment, running and preparing reports with pros and cons of statistics for each shift, coaching and disciplining, etc.
cons: This job is not for everyone. This is not hard work at all. In fact, it may be one of the easier jobs the University of Kentucky offers. However, this job does require a mental toughness in the beginning. You will get hung up on, speak with unhappy prospects and alumni, and told "No". However, if you can get through this for the first week or so, you will come to realize that it is not the worst thing in the world to get rejected. You have to keep on "Smiling and Dialing" - on to the next one. You are given much flexibility with your schedule, however, you are responsible for your schedule, and the shifts you sign up to work. There is little forgiveness for not showing up to a shift you signed up for and agreed to be there for - as with any job you will have in the real world after college.

review_title: The most horrifying, at times rewarding, job
job_title: Mental Health Associate in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros:
-Very few patients are very kind and respectful. Those individuals made my job more bearable.
-There are a couple of nurses that are phenomenal there. 
-It was a HUGE learning experience. I learned and experienced a lot while working with individuals who have mental health issues. It also helped me prioritize my values and what I want in life.
cons:
-Your managers and co-workers will not intervene if a patient is harassing you. Consider yourself a lone wolf while working there. 
-Your supervisor will ALWAYS take the patient's side, regardless of the argument or incident.

pros:
Aside from client drama, this is a very easy job. Only basic SQL skills are required, and if you stay on top of your work, little time input is needed. Most of your time will be spent waiting on information and paperwork from 3rd parties, so I would advise bringing a personal laptop or tablet to scroll social media while awaiting such.

What little training UK provides is generally high quality, so rest assured that if hired, they will get you where you need to be to do the job, and are great about helping you out when you're out of your depth or overwhelmed, though this won't happen outside the busy seasons at the beginning and end of each semester.

Some people like the relaxed nature of the job, where it doesn't take much effort, but I'd personally rather work and train hard to move up.
cons:
People are very set in their ways. The tech infrastructure is fairly outdated, they're dead set on Dell/Microsoft products, IT/devops (they put devops responsibilities on IT for the most part) is stubborn about new platform and software adoption, leadership is even more stubborn about new and better workflows, and the stagnation can make work feel like a grind. They lack many modern tools such as GUI data tools, NLP, and even basic scripting languages (they insist that everything be done strictly with SQL queries), and when combined with a large, wide, messy database, this can be difficult to work with, and will feel odd if you have outside experience. A lot of your job will be telling people "sorry, we can't do that" due to the technical limitations of the organization, despite the request being perfectly reasonable.

Clients are difficult no matter the area, but the ignorance and entitlement of clients here is above the norm, so be prepared. There have only been a couple incidents where this got truly out of hand in my time there, but assume that you'll get an angry/pushy email at least once or twice a day, including weekends (no obligation to answer until Monday). Clients typically know nothing about data either, so you'll have to do a lot of hand holding as you guide them through creating a useful data model/format, and then adjusting it numerous times as they come back weeks later suddenly unhappy with what they've agreed to. They don't know what they want, and it will be on you to to figure out what they want as you talk them through the process.

Lastly, there are practically no career advancement opportunities. Once you've been trained in basic to intermediate SQL, and given what little they have of a data dictionary, don't expect to learn anything else, nor rise in rank, because there's nowhere to go. This position has high turnover for this exact reason, because people will join, get the SQL training, and then study hard on their own, and then leave 1-2 years later when they realize they can do better in pay and benefits. The pay seems to be $50-60k, with or without PTO, 403b, etc., and while that's sufficient for a modest lifestyle in the area, one with the qualifications to work here can often do far better.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work if you get in the right department.
pros: Flex time, Free education for employees and discounts for family, lots of holiday time off for Christmas New Years holiday, decent pay.
cons: Some things not transparent such as fairness of performance evaluations, leadership varies among departments/colleges.  Some places you have to transfer to get a promotion (because no where to go) or raise (bad economy).

review_title: Many Opprtunities to Get Hours and Gain New Experiences
pros: There are so many entry level positions available that you can grab a ton of hours and the staff are willing to help you find more hours doing other jobs in their department. It is a great place to build your resume. Also, pay is good compared to other student jobs on campus.
cons: I have heard that just like any university department, politics can be a bother, though I never personally experienced it myself,

review_title: Young professional in a staff position, Poor experience
pros:
Retirement match was good, not sure about the status of it with COVID.

Good PTO for managers. Dedicated sick time for all staff.

If you’re a good employee faculty will find a spot for you. I’d consider it stable employment if you are very flexible about job duties.

Most departments are a good place to get a variety of research experience early in career and get your name on grants and papers.

Good resources and software available. 

Salaried employees can ask for flexible work options, many people are allowed a work from home day or two per week.

There are pumping rooms for breastfeeding but they may be a 10 minute walk across campus. 

Many research projects contribute to improving the lives of others.
cons:
As a staff, faculty changed my position duties significantly without making it official. Large portions of my time were given to to other units that were unrelated to what I was hired for. I feel like faculty frequently offered my time as a “favor” for other departments and it distracted from my main duties. It put me in a very awkward position. 

My career goals weren’t taken seriously, even though there is a yearly review where they were discussed.

Healthcare coverage is expensive unless you see all UK providers (and they’re not the best in town in my opinion). If you’re not seeing UK providers it was around $50 copay for me to see a specialist in network. Ask for the current details if you get an offer.

My office/desk may frequently moved according to what space faculty and senior staff wanted. But, some of the new buildings have enough office space. 

Buildings are just very old, consider this if you have health issues or sensitivities. 

Very low yearly raise.

I was given a very hard time about using my earned vacation time. They would often say “maybe” and not approve or deny it. In one instance I was told I couldn’t go on a trip the day before I had planned to leave, because of an issue with another staff member. I don’t think most staff experience this. There were some issues using sick time as well.

Salaried employees must give 4 weeks notice to leave.

Maternity policies aren’t good in my opinion. They take most of your sick and vacation leave and use it concurrently with FMLA. The most current policy is outlined in the employee staff handbook. Some supervisors will be nicer about it than others.

review_title: Great expericence as a graduate research assistant in the University of Kentucky
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington, KY
pros: Most people are very friendly. Lexington is a mid-size college town. Lots of young people. Life is pretty convenient if you have a car. Good work-life balance. Living expense is relatively cheap compared with east and west coasts. The weather is usually nice, and has clear four seasons. Close to great smoky mountains and mammoth cave.
cons: Do not have too many R&D job opportunities in Kentucky. Sometime can feel boring since there are not too many entertainment in town besides cinemas, bars or restaurants.

review_title: Good balance of support and autonomy
job_title: Student Program Coordinator in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros:
- Great pay for the responsibilities
- Collaborative work environment
- Management was supportive and encouraging
- Despite being a student employee, I felt that my boss had trust in me to perform my job well and gave me the autonomy to work independently.
- Clear expectations and good models for giving feedback
cons:
- Given that it was a student position, the hours of work I put in and responsibilities I was given could be stressful.
- Ineligible to get an employee parking pass despite being an employee who had an office in the building.

review_title: Highly recommend, good company to work for
pros: Communications department amazing - they foster cooperation and learning among staff and students. Their health comm program is top ten in the US. Incredibly supportive environment
cons: Some jobs do not pay very much, though most are very competitive. I can't think of any other cons of being an instructor at UK. I enjoyed my two years there and was sad to leave it.

pros: Great benefits, especially 401k 200% match!  Ample time off, vacation leave, holiday leave, and sick time.  Have nice tuition reimbursement policy as well, and will also pay for an advancing degree of 18 hours per year.
cons: Three 12 hour shifts per week, work is hard, and many times employees don't feel as if they have a say in their workplace and policies. Depending on the unit you work on greatly depends on the employee mentality.

review_title: Central Pharmacy: choose to kiss up or choose to be shown the door
pros: The best thing about UK is the benefits package which is one of the best in the state. The nurses can be quite pleasurable to speak to aswell.
cons: Do not value diversity in opinions background or culture. you will expected to fall in line and be grateful for the opportunity to be at UK

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: The school is pretty. There are many flowers blooming in spring and summer. They are doing renovation on many buildings so the infrastructure will be nice.
cons: Lexington doesn't offer too much excitement of city living. It is pretty much a flat town. If you have family, it will be a good place. But if you are by yourself, it is a quite boring place.

pros: Fast paced, excellent teaching hospital performing cutting edge procedures comparatively.  Great people, great students, great patients. Time off policy is great.
cons: Parking is a nightmare. Employer did not provide any formal training, expected to jump right in and learn everything on my own. Poor communication with manage my own. Pay is poor. I have many specializations but cant utilize any of my skills as a professional because Hospital is behind the times as far as what dietitians can and can’t do.

pros: Great job security and the fact there is always room to move up
cons: That you have to work long day and nights and sometimes be on call

pros: The benefits are great and it's a very flexible place to work-- great work/life balance. You can almost always get time off if you need to.
cons: The infrastructure of the university is terrible, though-- no one ever knows what's going on and it takes a million years to get anything done if you have to rely on people outside of your own office.

pros: The grounds were nice, the students mostly friendly, and the town is interesting.
cons: There is little support or training, there is a negative, hostile atmosphere, lower faculty and staff are treated badly, part time employees get no benefits and little pay, discrimination and snobbery of many kinds is rampant but often so covert it can only be felt and not addressed, talking the talk is the only really important thing, parking is a headache every day, insurance is not good, everything is overpriced, and diversity is given mostly lip service in many areas.

review_title: A great place to work; if you're in for the long haul
pros: A vibrant community that works for the good of the Commonwealth. Some of the sharpest minds work here and it's exciting to be among them. For a public university, compensation and benefits are fair and competitive.
cons: Political interests and domain protection often hinder moving the enterprise forward at its full potential. Because of long tenured employment, career advancement will take time. Funding constraints will continue to be a challenge unless an innovative financial model is instituted.

review_title: Academic Enhancement: The Study, Peer Tutor
pros:
- Intelligent Coworkers
- Reasonable and understanding management
- Great pay for college students
- Breaks during school holidays!
- Intrinsically rewarding
cons: There really isn't much I can speak poorly of "The Study"-- occasionally coworkers would slack off and management doesn't easily control or stop that, which forces you to work much harder, but I personally enjoyed the extra work at times.

pros: Senior level administration is very engaged in working to bring the campus buildings and residence halls to a modern level.  Strong school spirit amongst faculty, students and staff.
cons: Pay isn't great, although much better than most in the area - not good when compared to peer institutions. Sometimes feels as if too much focus is on the health sciences and the rest of the university is second fiddle.

review_title: Great support structure, friendly professional environment, but not strict on students
pros:
-) Associate with others of similar interests
-) Support for graduate students, including additional fellowships and conference funding
-) Sets high expectations and pushes you to meet them
-) Extremely friendly and supportive environment, making you look forward to working each day
cons:
-) Review for teachers is limited to student evaluations and a single in-class observation, making it difficult to receive feedback and react to it
-) Somewhat a "teach them to swim by throwing them in the deep end" situation

pros: University of Kentucky offers great benefits such as health and life insurance and access to their health care provider network. Also the Lexington community offers discounts to UK employees and faculty and the university is seen as a contributing and positive presence in the city. UK also offers good working conditions and I worked with a set of  outstanding colleagues who supported me in my position.
cons: The drawbacks to this position were the limited contract period and the lack of job security for follow on contracts.

job_title: Staff Support Associate II in Lexington, KY
pros: Can be hard to get your foot in the door, but once it's in expect to want to stay...benefits not offered to part-time employees, but tons of growth opportunities are. Enjoyed the culture and working with folks from diverse backgrounds.
cons:
No hazard pay for COVID-19 (yet)

Impossible to prove that you contracted COVID-19 from UK unless you have direct patient care

pros: only requires 3 shifts per week (usually evening) and 4 weekend shifts a month (friday eve, sat morning, or sunday daytime). The environment is very laid back, easy going supervisors and co-workers. The work is very easy
cons: Not a good place to work full time or depend for anything more than 20hrs a week, SRC can run out of numbers to call and people will stop working for a few weeks.  It's difficult to get day shifts from 12-4pm, and the hours are pretty rigid.

review_title: Great experience as a research assistant.Good mentors and professors. Wish the pay could have been increased
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Great health insurance package, professional colleagues, constant development/projects going on around campus. Lot's of service opportunities available around town. Town is not too big or too busy, horse racing and college basketball are big deals.
cons:
City gets crazy with students and town folks rampaging especially after the men's basketball games (win or lose :) ) during the NCAAB tournament. Steer clear of State Street and South Limestone on game nights.
Overall good place.

review_title: Good place to study and live
pros: Most people are very friendly. Everyone is looking to make friends and you always meet new people. You can enjoy UK basketball and study in amazing and beautiful Young Library.  No high traffic  in Lexington.
cons:
Teachers at UK don't care about their students - at least most of them don't, anyway.
There is nothing to do in the city of Lexington besides bars and frat parties that you cant go to unless your in the fraternity.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Students are offered the Assistantship and may choose professors to work for. The Chair of the Department--Dr. Ron--is excellent!
cons: The offer is only for 9 months, so $11106 divided by 12 months let you make $925 on a weighted monthly scale. Very low, but at least it pays(!) tuition (not fees though)

review_title: To the elite go the spoils...
pros: Time off during holidays
cons:
Terrible parking  
Low pay; support staff and non managerial staff are not valued and it shows in the poor compensation packages. 
Senior leadership is selfish and stagnating.

review_title: Great place to fulfill your professional dreams.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Supportive scientific community is essential for any scientist success and this place provides exactly that. Additionally,  plenty of resources are available in your pursuit to finding answers to the scientific questions. If the you can't find what you need on campus, friendly staff is always there to help find it off campus.
cons: Graduate student housing should have more apartments available, especially for international graduate students, postdocs and scholars. Also, those apartments should be new or renovated.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Goof life work balance, nice environment to work at, lively college city living experience. Staff are nice and friendly in general. Overall it is a good experience.
cons: The amount of payment can be better, the management can be disorganized sometimes, in terms of payroll. Sometimes it may take weeks to get a satisfactory answer from the manager.

review_title: Part-time Lab assistant job was simple and pay was fine.
job_title: Student Laboratory Assistant, Plant Pathology in Lexington, KY
pros: The lab members and staff are friendly and helpful.  I had this job as a student, so anything above minimum wage was a huge benefit and everyone understood working around class schedules.
cons: Performing the same task day in and day out became monotonous, but you were allowed to wear headphones which helped.  If you required a parking pass, you had to pay for it out-of-pocket.

job_title: Research Support Staff in Lexington, KY
pros:
- Great staff to work with; everyone is very personable and easy to talk to.
- Tasks are not difficult, little training needed for my job.
- Flexible work hours.
cons:
- Limited to work study students.
- Set pay scale based on year in school.
- Small work area, but it depends on which department you work with.

pros: The benefits are fantastic. Very affordable health insurance, tuition discounts, they double your retirement contribution which is something I have never seen anywhere else.  The retirement benefit alone is worth working here. Pay rates are very competitive for the area, shift diffs are available for nights/weekend shifts
cons: parking is expensive (aprox $400-700/year depending on location) and the locations are inconvenient.  Most nurses park at the football stadium and ride a bus to work.

job_title: Account Clerk III in Lexington, KY
pros: Fantastic benefits, excellent work-life balance support, very good job stability, great in-house training opportunities, paid classes for employees at state universities, 50% tuition discount for dependants.
cons: Low pay, few raises, very difficult to get interviews.

review_title: Office of Residence life provides good job opportunities for students.
job_title: Night Desk Clerk in Lexington, KY
pros: Provides a raise (for night desk clerks) after a year of employment. Able to get paid while working on school work.
cons: Low pay. Difficult to obtain "good" weekday shifts. Little accountability for employees sometimes leads to having to stay late until someone can take over when person who was supposed to follow you doesn't show up.

pros: There is so much available as far as programs for furthering your education, training, benefits, etc. The University wants its employees to succeed in their careers and they offer many tools to allow employees to do so.
cons: There are so many employees with the medical center and faculty and staff, as well as students, parking can be a nightmare during the day. You will definitely get your exercise walking to work!

pros: There are some really good people working here. UK is undergoing a lot of change right now so that can make it really exciting. The benefits are really good.
cons: Working with faculty can be difficult at times. They tend to hate policies and procedures and trying to get them to follow the rules can be extremely frustrating. There is still less advancement for women and minorities. There is still a lot of sexism and racism on campus.

pros: good working environment, nice people, good place to live. A middle size city which has everything, but not very crowded. I like Lexington, so U of Kentucky is a good place to work.
cons: U of Kentucky is a different employer now, especially after 2012. The new president cares more about making money and cut off a lot of research funding. I think UKY will eventually turns to a non-research school.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington, KY
pros: Paid tuition as a research assistant was very helpful. I enjoyed my time at University of Kentucky and learned a lot to help my career move forward.
cons: Lack of structure in my lab kept me from being as productive as I could be. Must be very independent to be successful.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Great benefits and a decent work pace. If you like to help students, it's right up your alley.
cons: Pay could be better, but it's a public sector job, so what do you expect. Management and employees aren't always the best, and those that are lacking take forever to get rid of.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Considering the cost in a city like Lexjngton, University of Kentucky provides their TA a sufficient living stipend. We do have a great environment for our graduate study.
cons: The city is kind of boring. The college itself need to improve their academic level. And we do need more career advice.

pros: Good Benefits, Many different jobs available, Good place for entry level work, ok school for career advancement, decent healthcare system
cons: too many reorgs, raises and job security not certain, lots of incompetent managers, people have atittude that you are either a short timer or here for life.

pros: excelent working environment, very good facilities, excellent place for agriculture, Lexington is a lovely city to live, small by with an excellent cultural life and beautiful places to visit
cons: On the agriculture point fo view is not a big state for wheat the crop I work no. The traffic is very heavy at the university, they should put all biking lines to move around campus. public transportation is very bad in lexingotn

pros: Great Benefits and lots of room for advancement. Thorough training and was a great job for a student with down time to work on homework during 2nd shift.
cons: If you are a hard worker it was easy to overwork yourself due to lazy coworkers that management let happen

pros: With a lot of departments and it's large size, it is easy to move around within the organization. The tuition waiver is a nice bonus.

Incompetence is common in every department. The benefits are not nearly as good as people outside UK think they are.

pros: Good opportunities to start up at entry level. They pay you the examinations if any  is needed to be taken. You can manage your time, pay vacations and full benefits.
cons: If you wanna keep growing in a career pathway you have to move to a different area.  Only three people can leave the same day from the whole area so you have to schedule or reschedule sometimes your doctors appointments.

pros: My pay was ok, benefits were good, and there was little stress in the office space. Have worked in worse places.
cons: Office politics were pretty big there, affected a lot of projects. You have to deal with legacy code constantly, so if you enjoy that, more power to you.

pros: UK has a nice campus, some dedicated students, some conscientious faculty, some helpful staff, some satisfactory teaching facilities, and a good library..
cons: Too many bad apples in this barrel:  administrators who operate with neither transparency nor accountability, who don't really care about excellence in teaching, research or service to the Commonwealth, but do care about their extravagantly inflated salaries and rewarding their privileged coteries.

pros:

cons: Upper Administration is very heavy.  If more time and money was spent on the education of the students and support staff, it would be a much better place to work.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: All management staff is extremely courteous and works great with student schedules for work times, even during midterms and finals.  Library patrons are actually friendly, compared to working at other positions/locations, and you get to meet a variety of people from the general public and prospective students themselves or their family.
cons: The pay could have been better as working for minimum wage hurts when paying bills.

review_title: Hard to get on as employee but amazing benefits ($40 mo. healthcare)
job_title: Help Desk Tech in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros:
great health insurance
401k that matches your contribution
required to have 401k if 30 orolder
cons:
hard to get hired
Competitive
if you start as a STEPS employee then it is hard to get hired on full time. Good to have a steps position b/c you will be considered before the general public but you need to continue to apply to UK (non-STEPS) positions.

pros: Benefits, close to residence, provides educaitonal oppourtunities for myself and my family, some employees are great to work with at the college.

review_title: Nice place and staff supporting your research
pros: The staff are nice and supportive; Nice town to live in; Facilities are convenient. HR and management team handle the request quickly. IT support are also great to solve the problems for you.
cons: The University budget is cutting, especially for the next fiscal year. There are no other complain besides this. University of Kentucky at Lexington is an idea place for work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington-Fayette, KY

cons: Low hourly rates, patient population can be very tough to deal with. Low staffing.

pros: Opportunity to gain lots of experience on a range of health care areas.

pros: Lots of time off, plenty of rewarding opportunities, good leadership.

pros:

Helping patients

pros: Depending on the department where you work, there can be a great sense of camaraderie. It is relatively easy to maintain a good work/life balance. There are a number of opportunities to work on interesting projects.

pros: This is a great place to work. The work-life balance is great, and the University really goes out of its way to make employees feel valued and appreciated. The benefits are great, and they offer a great deal of perks to their employees.
